column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=4. Methodology
#Text=In order to perform pollution risk assessment , vulnerability as well as hazard assessment have to be performed in advance .
#Text=The whole procedure is displayed in the flowchart in
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=.
#Text=Firstly , the four parameters have to be determined to apply the Epikarst , Protective Cover , Infiltration Conditions and Degree of Karstic Network Development ( EPIK ) method .
#Text=Therefore , each parameter is assigned with category values , ranging from 1 – 3 or 1 – 4 .
#Text=For the evaluation of the four parameters of the EPIK method , various tools can be used besides .
#Text=In this case study , geomorphological maps were used in order to determine the Epikarst parameter ( E ) .
#Text=Remote sensing and aerial photography can be used for further investigation , as well as field investigation .
#Text=Additionally , hydrogeophysical methods are useful and essential for the Epikarst determination and karst aquifer structure .
#Text=For the definition of the P factor , the present soil , as well as geological formations covering the karst aquifer , are taken into account .
#Text=Due to its practicability , only the thickness of the protective cover is considered .
#Text=Therefore , geological maps in combination with satellite pictures were used , based on existing data .

#Text=The I and K parameters were determined with the help of ArcGIS , more precise , digital elevation and slope models were used , based on the data available from the study of Voudouris et al. and Nikolaou .
#Text=The determination of the K parameter is usually based on direct identification through the presence of caves or swallow holes .
#Text=In this case study , further indirect methods , based on flow hydrograph analysis , tracer tests , as well as water quality examination , had to be used .
#Text=Subsequently , ArcGIS Software was utilized for the preparation of single parameter maps (
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=) .
#Text=Accordingly , to its protective function , the parameters are weighted , and last of all , added up obtaining the values for the four parameters .
#Text=The following Equation ( 1 ) describes the process for calculating the protection index F : ( 1 )
#Text=The indices , α = 3 , β = 1 , γ = 3 and δ = 2 are determined by Doerfliger and Zwahlen and represent the weighting coefficients for each parameter .
#Text=The indices Ei , Pj , Ik , and Ki represent the ratings of each parameter .
#Text=The vulnerability values range from 9 – 34 and are ranked in four classes .
#Text=Low values of the protection index F signify a higher vulnerability of the karst aquifer .
#Text=Following Equation ( 1 ) , and by using raster calculator in GIS , the vulnerability map was created (
#Text=Figure 6
#Text=) .
#Text=Additionally , a single parameter sensitivity analysis was implemented .

#Text=The sensitivity analysis is a dynamic tool that helps the analyst to judge the significance of subjectivity components and provides essential information on the influence of the weights of each parameter .
#Text=The sensitivity analysis performed according to Equation 2 using raster calculator within the toolbox of ArcGIS , is as follows : W = [ ( Pr × Pw )/ V ] × 100 ( 2 ) where :
#Text=W = the effective weight of each parameter ( % )
#Text=Pr = the parameter ’s rating
#Text=Pw = the parameter ’s weight
#Text=V = the aggregated value of the applied index .
#Text=Subsequent to the validation of the parameters and the creation of the final vulnerability map , the hazard map was prepared .
#Text=The hazard map in this context describes the potential threat of pollution and was produced with ArcGIS by taking Corine land use data and possible pollution sources into account .
#Text=More detailed , the hazard map was adapted in ArcGIS , according to the present pollution sources mentioned in Table 1 .
#Text=The pollution risk map depicts the areas in which it is most likely that groundwater will be polluted , caused by human activities .
#Text=The risk is very high , where high vulnerable zones and dangerous hazards come together .
#Text=For this case study , the risk map was evaluated by overlaying the vulnerability and hazard map , following Equation ( 3 ) . ( 3 )
